data.title: Presidentâs Circle
data.meta_description: Presidentâs Circle members are a dedicated group of supporters who give annual gifts of $10,000 or more to advance Fred Hutchâs mission of eliminating cancer.
data.text:
Dr. Sue Biggins studies how cells divide and distribute their chromosomes, a process that is almost always disrupted in cancer. The major structure involved in maintaining the precision of this process is the kinetochore, but understanding its functionality eluded scientists. During a pivotal point in her research, Dr. Biggins received Presidentâs Circle funding that allowed her to devise a new technique to better study the kinetochore, which has important implications for treating cancer.

Dave Jacksonâs world turned upside down five years ago when he was diagnosed with kidney cancer. âNo one can be prepared for the words, âYou have cancer,ââ he said. When Daveâs oncologist told him research on developing immunotherapy for kidney cancer was limited because there wasnât funding available, Dave set out to change that. His philanthropic efforts brought about the first program for kidney cancer research at Fred Hutch.

HIV-positive people are at a substantially higher risk of developing some types of cancer compared with uninfected people. Dr. Hans-Peter Kiem, a stem cell transplant and gene therapy researcher at Fred Hutch, received $50,000 in private support to investigate how genetically modified stem cells could play a role in curing HIV. Early results from Dr. Kiemâs research in altering an HIV-infected personâs stem cells were so promising that the initial investment from donors led to $43 million over 10 years in funding from the National Institutes of Health.

Dr. Pete Nelson studies prostate cancer, with a focus on patients whose tumors have metastasized, or spread, from their original locations â a sign that the tumor is aggressive. During a pivotal point in his research, Dr. Nelson received Presidentâs Circle funding that allowed him to seamlessly continue investigating the alterations that contribute to a tumorâs aggressiveness.
